questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Bhilawanol

 

Explanation:

The image of the marking nut is Bhilawanol-Semecarpus Anacardium

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • It is used to create artificial bruises (malingering) but is not commonly used for Arrow and cattle poisoning.
  • Abrus precatorius is used as an arrow poison and ideal cattle poison.

 

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • Commonly known as the marking nut or bhilawanol (washermen use its juice to inscribe identification numbers on clothes).
  • Seeds:
    • Black, cone/heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.
    • They have a thick pericarp that contains an acrid, brownish, oily juice that turns black upon exposure to air.
  • Active principles: Semecarpol and Bhilawanol
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Skin exposure: Applying the juice can cause irritation, itching, and painful blisters filled with acrid serum. Eczematous eruptions resembling bruises may also occur, potentially evolving into ulcers with sloughing.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever and painful micturition, often accompanied by brown-colored urine.
    • Oral ingestion: A large dose can cause blisters in the mouth and throat, severe gastrointestinal irritation, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, loss of reflexes, delirium, coma, and potentially death.
    • Fatal dose: Approximately 5–10 g (5–8 seeds).
    • Fatal period: 12–24 hours.
  • Treatment:
    • Rinse the affected skin with soap and water.
    • Apply bland liniments.
    • Provide demulcent drinks and symptomatic treatment.
  • Medico-legal Aspects:
    • Criminal Use: The juice can be introduced vaginally as a form of punishment for infidelity or applied to the cervical os for illegal abortions.
    • Malingering: The juice can simulate conjunctivitis or falsely substantiate assault claims, as the lesions resemble bruises

 Ricin (Option A) is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

Abrin (Option C) is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

Calotropin (Option D) is a cardiac glycoside found in plants of the Calotropis genus, such as Calotropis gigantea and Calotropis procera.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning?

 

1. Raindrop pigmentation 

2. Peripheral neuritis 

3. Mees line 

4. Luminous vomit
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2, 3 are correct

 

Explanation

Chronic arsenic poisoning commonly presents with raindrop pigmentation, peripheral neuritis, and Mees lines, making Option A the correct answer.

 

Clinical manifestations of Arsenic Poisoning:

 

Acute Arsenic Poisoning

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning

Dermal

  • Hair loss
  • Mees lines (Aldrich-Mees line or Reynold’s line): Transverse bands of opacity in nails.
  • Melanosis (neck, eyelids, nipples)
  • Bowen’s disease
  • Facial oedema
  • Hyperkeratosis
  • Black foot disease (Peripheral gangrene)
 
  • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pattern)
 
  • Skin cancer (commonly squamous cell carcinoma).

Ocular

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Lacrimation

Dimension of Vision

Gastrointestinal

  • Abdominal pain
  • Metallic taste
  • Garlicky odour
  • Dysphagia
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea (bloody or rice water)
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Weight loss

Airway

Upper airway irritation
  • Nasal septum perforation
  • Laryngitis
  • Bronchitis

Liver

Fatty degeneration
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Cirrhosis

Kidney

  • Oliguria
  • Uraemia

Nephritic changes

Neurological

  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Convulsions
  • Coma
  • Encephalopathy
  • Polyneuritis (glove & stocking type)

 

  • Tremor
  • Ataxia
  • Limb tenderness
  • Difficulty in walking

Haematological

–
  • Anaemia
  • Leucopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Basophilic stippling (Rare in arsenic poisoning and common in lead poisoning)
  •  
  • Karyorrhexis
  • Pancytopenia

Cardiac

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Hypertension
  • Myocarditis

 

Luminous vomit: This is not associated with chronic arsenic poisoning but can occur in acute poisoning due to phosphorus ingestion.

questions.text: Identify the given plant based on its features
questions.solution:
The above image matches the characteristics of Argemone Mexicana, known for its yellow flowers and toxic properties.

 

  • Argemone Mexicana:
    • Commonly known as prickly poppy.
    • The plant is characterized by its yellow flowers, prickly leaves, and a milky sap.
    • It is toxic due to alkaloids such as sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine, which can cause health issues like epidemic dropsy.

 

Argemone Mexicana (Prickly Poppy)

Toxic Parts

Entire plant; seeds resemble mustard seeds but are darker with minute projections.

Toxic Oil

Argemone oil (katkar oil) causes epidemic dropsy.

Active Principles

Plant Alkaloids: Berberine, Protopine.

Oil Alkaloids: Sanguinarine, Dihydrosanguinarine. (Cause abnormal blood vessel permeability.)

General Symptoms

Gradual onset with appetite loss, diarrhea, leg edema, and generalized anasarca.

System-Specific Signs

Heart: Myocardial damage, heart dilatation.

CVS: Hypotension, breathlessness, feeble pulse.

Hepatic: Enlarged, tender liver.

PNS: Tingling, hyperesthesia, calf muscle tenderness, reduced or absent jerks.

Ocular: Dim vision due to increased intraocular pressure.

Skin: Bluish mottling from peripheral vessel dilation.

Fatal Outcome

Severe heart damage.

Treatment

Balanced diet, decontamination, cessation of oil consumption, diuretics, corticosteroids, and supportive care.

Medico-Legal Aspects

Argemone oil is commonly used to adulterate mustard or other edible oils.


 

Datura Alba (Option A): Known as white datura, it has white trumpet-shaped flowers and is associated with anticholinergic toxicity.

Nerium Odorum (Option C): Known as oleander, it has pink or white flowers and contains cardiac glycosides causing poisoning.

Papaver Somniferum (Option D): Commonly known as the opium poppy, it produces latex rich in alkaloids like morphine and codeine.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning?
questions.solution:
The primary treatment for acute arsenic poisoning is dimercaprol, a chelating agent that binds arsenic and facilitates its excretion.

 

Management of Arsenic Poisoning

 

Supportive treatment

Gastric lavage, airway, breathing, and circulation management (intravenous fluids, cardiac monitoring, etc.).

Medical treatment

Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide (chemical antidote)

Chelating agents
  • BAL (Dimercaprol)
  • DMSA (Dimercapto succinic acid) or DMPS (Dimercapto propane sulfonic acid)
  • Penicillamine

Other measures
  • Purgatives like Castor oil or Magnesium sulfate (remove unabsorbed poison from the intestine).
  • Glucose-saline with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis or exchange transfusion.

 

Ipecac (Option A): Previously used to induce vomiting but is no longer recommended due to the risk of aspiration and limited efficacy.

Penicillamine (Option B): Another chelating agent, primarily used for copper poisoning (e.g., Wilson’s disease). Less effective than dimercaprol in arsenic toxicity.

Activated charcoal (Option C): Used for gastrointestinal decontamination in various poisonings. Not effective in chelating or removing absorbed arsenic.

questions.text: Which of these is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Atropa belladonna, also known as "Deadly Nightshade," contains tropane alkaloids (atropine, scopolamine). While it affects the autonomic nervous system (causing tachycardia, dry mouth, and dilated pupils), it is not classified as a direct cardiac poison.

 

Some common cardiac poisons include:

  • Aconite (Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox)
  • Nicotine (Nicotiana tabacum)
  • Digitalis (Digitalis purpurea)
  • Oleander (Cerbera thevetia, Cerbera odorum)
  • Quinine.

 

Aconite (Option A):

  • Aconite is cardiac poison derived from the Aconitum plant.
  • It causes arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest by altering sodium channel function.

Cerbera thevetia (Option B): Commonly known as the "Yellow Oleander," it contains cardiac glycosides that interfere with the sodium-potassium ATPase pump.

 

Nicotiana tabacum (Option C): Tobacco contains nicotine, which can act on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and cause tachycardia or bradycardia depending on the dose.

questions.text: Gastric lavage, commonly known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is a procedure performed to remove the contents of the stomach. It has been widely used since the early 19th century as a standard method to eliminate toxins from the stomach. This procedure is typically employed for individuals who have consumed poison or overdosed on substances like ethanol. Additionally, it may be performed prior to surgery to empty the digestive tract. In which of the following situations is gastric lavage not recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydrocarbons

Explanation:

Gastric Lavage in Poisoning Management

  • Gastric lavage is a procedure to remove ingested poison by introducing and withdrawing fluids through an orogastric tube. Its effectiveness depends on timing, proper technique, and patient-specific considerations.

Timing and Effectiveness

  • Most effective within 1 hour of ingestion
  • Can be beneficial up to 4-6 hours in select cases
  • Beyond 6 hours, poison likely passes into the intestines, reducing lavage efficacy

Procedure Steps

Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Contraindications

  • Corrosive Poisoning: Avoid except for carbolic acid (phenol) to prevent perforation
  • Convulsant Poisons: Risk of triggering seizures (e.g., strychnine)
  • Comatose Patients: High aspiration risk
  • Volatile Poisons/ Hydrocarbons: May cause aspiration pneumonitis
  • Risk of Hemorrhage/ Perforation: Avoid if esophageal varices or recent surgery present
  • Additional Contraindications to Emetics
    • Severe heart or lung diseases
    • Advanced pregnancy
    • CNS depression or seizures

Complications

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternatives to Gastric Lavage

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

Incorrect Options:

Organophosphate poisoning (Option A): Gastric lavage is recommended for organophosphate poisoning (e.g., insecticides) because it can effectively remove the poison from the stomach if performed early, particularly within 1 hour of ingestion. The risks of aspiration or complications are considered manageable in this case with proper techniques.

Ethanol poisoning (Option C): Gastric lavage is recommended in cases of ethanol poisoning if it is performed within 1 hour of ingestion. Ethanol is rapidly absorbed, so the procedure is most effective if performed early. Gastric lavage may help prevent further absorption of the alcohol and reduce toxicity.

PCM (Paracetamol/Acetaminophen) toxicity (Option D): In PCM toxicity, gastric lavage is used if the patient presents within a few hours of ingestion, particularly in cases of massive overdose. It helps remove remaining drug from the stomach before it is absorbed into the bloodstream.

questions.text: In case of corrosive acid ingestion, stomach is opened along the?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Greater curvature

  • In forensic autopsies, the stomach is usually opened along the greater curvature to minimize disruption of stomach anatomy and allows the pathologist to collect and examine the stomach contents effectively, which is critical in cases of suspected poisoning.

Procedure for Stomach Dissection:

  1. Two ligatures are applied at the cardiac end of the esophagus and two ligatures are below the pyloric end of the stomach.
  2. The stomach is removed by cutting between the double ligatures at both ends.
  3. The stomach is then opened along the greater curvature.
  4. The mucous membrane is examined for the presence of any stains, congestion, hemorrhage, desquamation, ulceration, sloughing, or perforation.
  5. The contents of the stomach are noted with respect to quantity, nature of material/food, state of digestion, color, and smell.

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Huffing

  • Huffing involves inhaling the vapors of an inhalant, typically from a cloth or rag soaked in volatile solvents.
  • It is a method where the substance is directly inhaled through the mouth, and a cloth soaked in the drug is commonly used for this method.
  • Inhalants are substances that produce intoxicating vapors when inhaled, often used by young adolescents.
  • They can cause severe health issues, including cardiac arrest, suffocation, and long-term damage to the brain, heart, kidneys, and liver.

Types of Inhalants:

  1. Volatile Solvents: Liquids that vaporize at room temperature, found in household and business products like paint thinners, dry-cleaning fluids, gasoline, glues, and felt-tip markers.
  2. Aerosols: Products that release vapors when sprayed, such as spray paints, deodorant sprays, hair sprays, and cooking oil sprays.
  3. Gases: Gases like nitrous oxide (laughing gas), chloroform, ether, and halothane, used in medical procedures. Also includes gases found in butane lighters, propane tanks, and refrigerants.
  4. Nitrites: Sold in small bottles called “poppers,” these primarily dilate blood vessels and relax muscles, acting differently from other inhalants that affect the central nervous system.

Bagging (Option A): This involves inhaling vapors from a substance stored in a plastic bag. It is a common method of inhaling gases or solvents but does not specifically refer to inhaling a cloth soaked in a drug.

Spraying (Option B): This refers to inhaling vapors directly from an aerosol or spray can, such as spray paints or deodorant sprays. It is a method of inhaling aerosol inhalants, but it does not apply to inhaling from a cloth soaked in a drug.

Sniffing (Option D): This involves inhaling vapors directly from a container or surface, such as sniffing glue or other substances. However, it does not specifically refer to inhaling from a cloth soaked in a drug.

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer was presented in the hospital with pinpoint pupil & increased secretions. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Organophosphorus poisoning

  • The symptoms of pinpoint pupils (miosis) and increased secretions (such as salivation, lacrimation, and bronchorrhea) are highly suggestive of organophosphorus poisoning. Organophosphates inhibit cholinesterase enzymes, leading to the accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.

Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

Alcohol poisoning (Option A): Alcohol typically causes CNS depression, but does not cause pinpoint pupils or excessive secretions

Opioid poisoning (Option B): Opioids cause miosis (pinpoint pupils) but do not cause excessive secretions or the broad range of symptoms seen in organophosphorus poisoning.\

Datura poisoning (Option D): Datura causes mydriasis (dilated pupils) and other anticholinergic symptoms like dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia, which are opposite to the muscarinic symptoms caused by organophosphorus poisoning.

questions.text: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - HCN poisoning

  • Cyanide poisoning (HCN) causes pink skin and mucosa, bitter almond odor from the breath, and frothy discharge, which are key diagnostic clues. It is caused by the exposure to hydrogen cyanide (HCN) or cyanide salts. Cyanide interferes with cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase, an enzyme in the mitochondria, leading to histotoxic anoxia (cells cannot use oxygen, even when it is available in the bloodstream).

Cyanide poisoning

Physical Appearance
  • Gaseous state- Hydrogen cyanide (HCN)
  • Liquid form- Hydrocyanic acid or Prussic acid
  • Solid state- salt forms

Sources of poisoning
  • Electroplating, photographic processes, rubber, and plastic manufacturing industries
  • Insecticide and rodenticide
  • Drug toxicity: Sodium nitroprusside
  • Military chemical warfare agents
  • Burning of plastic furniture, silk, or wool
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Bitter almonds, peach, apricot, plum, apple, pear, cassava

Mode of Action
  • Rapid absorption across both skin and mucous membrane
  • Cyanide salts combine with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to form HCN that is absorbed
  • Inhibition of cytochrome oxidase causes histotoxic anoxia
  • Neurotoxicity

Clinical Features
  • Inhalation: Dizziness, vertigo, and constriction of the throat
  • Ingestion: Nausea, headache, loss of muscular power, hypotension, cardiovascular failure, and convulsion
  • Skin: Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Anion gap metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis

Diagnosis
  • Lee-Jones test
  • Serum cyanide level

Treatment
  • Severe acidosis (pH < 7.1): Administer sodium bicarbonate
  • Antidotal therapy (Eli Lilly cyanide kit approach)
    • First step: Inhalation of Amyl nitrite
    • Second step: Sodium nitrite (3% solution) IV
    • Third step: Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) IV
  • Other Antidotes
    • 4-dimethylaminophenol (4-DMAP)
    • Hydroxocobalamin (Vitamin B12): Combines with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted in the urine
    • Hyperbaric oxygen
  • Note: Methylene blue is NOT an antidote for cyanide and must NOT be used

Autopsy Findings
  • Bitter almond’s odour
  • Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Cyanosis of extremities
  • Hemorrhagic gastritis
  • Disseminated petechiae in brain, meninges, pleura, lungs, and pericardium
  • Pulmonary and cerebral edema

Note:

  • Mechanism of action of nitrites: It converts hemoglobin to methemoglobinemia which causes the detachment of cyanide from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.
  • Mechanism of action of sodium thiosulfate: Forms non-toxic thiocyanate which is excreted in the urine.

H2S poisoning (Option A): Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) poisoning typically presents with rotten egg smell from the breath, not the bitter almond smell seen in cyanide poisoning. Symptoms include headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and in severe cases, respiratory failure. The skin typically does not have the pink color seen in cyanide poisoning.

CO poisoning (Option B): Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning leads to a cherry-red skin color, not pink as seen in cyanide poisoning. The breath does not have a bitter almond smell, and the classic symptoms are headache, dizziness, confusion, and weakness, not frothy discharge.

OPC poisoning (Option D): Organophosphate (OP) poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as muscarinic effects (e.g., excessive salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, gastrointestinal distress) and nicotinic effects (muscle weakness, paralysis). The skin does not have a characteristic pink color, and there is no bitter almond odor from the breath. Frothy discharge is not a typical symptom of OPC poisoning.

questions.text: Which poisoning is caused by a bullet retained inside the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Lead

  • Lead is a toxic substance that can be released from retained lead bullets, especially if the bullet is lodged in the body for a prolonged period. Lead gradually leaches into the bloodstream and can cause neurological issues (e.g., confusion, memory problems, and in extreme cases, encephalopathy), kidney damage, gastrointestinal symptoms, and anemia.

Causes of Chronic Lead Poisoning:

  1. Ingestion or Inhalation of lead-containing dust.: Most common source
  2. Lead Paint Dust:
    • Major source for children, especially those under 3 years old.
    • Children are at greater risk due to pica (eating non-nutritive materials).
  3. Inhalation by Occupational Exposure: Workers in industries such as white lead manufacturing, lead paint production, plumbing, glass polishing, printing, and glass blowing are at risk.
  4. Contaminated Drinking Water: Absorption of lead from water stored in lead cisterns.
  5. Lead in Tinned Food
  6. Cosmetics and Hair Dyes
  7. Petrol and Gasoline: Percutaneous absorption of tetraethyl lead
  8. Lead absorption from vermilion (red pigment) used on the scalp.
  9. Lead poisoning can result from retained lead bullets or projectiles lodged in the body.

Iron (Option A): Not related to retained bullets. Iron poisoning typically occurs from ingesting large amounts of iron and affects the gastrointestinal system, liver, and kidneys.

Phosphorus (Option B): Occurs from exposure to white phosphorus and causes damage to the liver, but not associated with retained bullets.

Nitrocellulose (Option C): Found in gunpowder, but it does not cause poisoning from retained bullets.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of antidotes and toxicities is correctly matched?

choices.text:
Organophosphorus - Physostigmine
B) Atropine - L-carnitine
C) Benzodiazepine - Flumazenil
D) Arsenic - Desferrioxamine

questions.solution:
Benzodiazepine - Flumazenil : Flumazenil is a specific benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and is used to reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation or overdose.

Antidotes and their mechanisms

Poisoning Type

Antidote

Mechanism

Arsenic

(Option D ruled out)

BAL (Dimercaprol)

IM, chelates arsenic for excretion.

Succimer (DMSA)

Oral chelation.

DMPS

IV, transitioned to oral chelation.

Copper

Potassium Ferrocyanide

Forms insoluble copper complexes, reducing absorption.

Penicillamine

Chelates copper.

Cyanide

Sodium Nitrite

Forms methemoglobin to bind cyanide.

Sodium Thiosulfate

Converts cyanide to thiocyanate for renal excretion.

Hydroxocobalamin

Binds cyanide, forming cyanocobalamin.

Dicobalt Edetate, Methylene Blue

Alternative antidotes.

Ethylene Glycol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase to prevent toxic metabolites.

Iron

Desferrioxamine

Chelates iron for excretion.

Magnesium Hydroxide/Sodium Bicarbonate

 

Note: BAL should not be used in iron, cadmium, or selenium poisoning due to formation of toxic complexes.

Precipitate iron, reducing absorption.

Lead

Sodium/Magnesium Sulfate

Forms insoluble lead sulfate.

Calcium Chloride/Gluconate

Promotes bone deposition of lead.

CaNa2EDTA + BAL

Chelation therapy for lead elimination.

Mercury

Sodium Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate

Reduces toxic mercury ions.

BAL (Dimercaprol)

Traditional chelator; oral agents preferred.

Methanol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Compete for alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing toxic metabolites.

Opium

Naloxone

Blocks opioid receptors, reversing opioid effects.

Organophosphate

(Option A ruled out)

Atropine

Blocks muscarinic receptors to manage cholinergic symptoms.

Pralidoxime (2-PAM) (Option B ruled out)

Reactivates acetylcholinesterase.

Phenol

Magnesium Sulfate

Absorbs phenol in the stomach.

Phosphorus

Potassium Permanganate

Oxidizes phosphorus into harmless phosphates.

Strychnine

Barbiturates

Depress CNS, preventing seizures.

Thallium

Prussian Blue

Binds thallium in the intestine, preventing absorption.

Atropine - L-carnitine (Option B): Atropine poisoning is treated with physostigmine, a cholinesterase inhibitor that crosses the blood-brain barrier. L-carnitine has no role in atropine toxicity.

questions.text: What is the cause of death in smoke inhalation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anemic hypoxia

Explanation:

  • The primary cause of death in smoke inhalation is anemic hypoxia, which occurs due to the inability of hemoglobin to effectively transport oxygen to tissues. This condition can arise from carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, a common consequence of smoke inhalation. CO has a much higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, which leads to reduced oxygen delivery to vital organs, ultimately causing systemic hypoxia and potential organ failure.

Incorrect Options:

Histotoxic hypoxia (Option A) occurs when cells are unable to effectively use oxygen, often due to the presence of toxic substances, such as cyanide. While cyanide can be released during combustion, histotoxic hypoxia is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation. The main mechanism of death in smoke inhalation is related to the impaired ability of hemoglobin to carry oxygen, as seen in anemic hypoxia.

Ischemic hypoxia (Option B) results from inadequate blood flow to tissues, which can lead to a shortage of oxygen supply. In severe cases of smoke inhalation, respiratory failure could reduce oxygen perfusion to tissues, but this is not the primary cause of death in most cases of smoke inhalation. The main issue is the impaired oxygen binding by hemoglobin due to carbon monoxide (CO), leading to anemic hypoxia.

All of the above (Option D): While histotoxic hypoxia and ischemic hypoxia can be involved in some cases of smoke inhalation (especially if toxic gases like cyanide are present), anemic hypoxia is the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation due to the carbon monoxide (CO) binding to hemoglobin. Therefore, "All of the above" is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A little boy was playing in a garden. Suddenly, he collapsed and was rushed to the hospital. His friend who played with him in the garden informed the doctors that he ate one of the fruits in the garden post which he seemed to have developed these symptoms. He also had irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Datura, Physostigmine

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Toxins and Antidotes:

Toxicity

Antidote

Mechanism of action

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme

Opium

Naloxone

Opioid receptor antagonist

Organophosphates

Atropine

Pralidoxime

Muscarinic antagonist

Cholinesterase reactivation

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Replenishes Glutathione

Methanol

Fomepizole

Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Inhibits GABA receptors

Cyanide

Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach)
  1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide.
  1. Sodium nitrate: causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.
  • Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given.
  1. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate.

Datura, Pralidoxime (Option A) Pralidoxime, is an antidote used for organophosphate poisoning, not specifically for Datura poisoning. Organophosphates are a different class of toxic compounds that inhibit acetylcholinesterase, but they have different mechanisms of action compared to Datura alkaloids.

Yellow oleander, Digoxin and Yellow oleander, Physostigmine (Option C and D)

  • Yellow oleander (Thevetia peruviana) is a plant that contains cardiac glycosides, particularly Thevetin A and Thevetin B. Ingestion of yellow oleander can lead to cardiac toxicity, including arrhythmias, conduction disturbances, and cardiac arrest
  • Digoxin, is a cardiac glycoside commonly used in the treatment of heart failure and certain cardiac arrhythmias. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and overdose or toxicity can result in various cardiac manifestations, including arrhythmias.

questions.text: A young teenage boy with a history of drug abuse had been instilled with a shot of intravenous cocaine at a party. He is rushed to the emergency room by his friends. Some of the symptoms were diaphoresis, headache, and acute coronary spasm. Which of the following symptoms noted would go against the likely diagnosis of cocaine poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bradycardia

  • The symptoms of cocaine poisoning typically include diaphoresis (excessive sweating), headache, acute coronary spasm leading to myocardial ischemia (reduced blood flow to the heart), and agitation. Cocaine use usually leads to tachycardia (rapid heart rate) as one of its effects on the cardiovascular system.

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless (Option D)
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate (Option B)
  • Increase in temperature (Option C)
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction (Option A)
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image shown below?

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

Explanation:

In plants like Aconitum (commonly known as aconite or monkshood), all parts of the plant, including the roots, leaves, and flowers, are toxic. The plant contains potent alkaloids such as aconitine, which can cause poisoning if ingested.

 

Species

Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox

Synonyms

Monk’s hood, mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket

Source
  • All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A)
  • Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root)
  • Grown in Mountainous areas of the northern hemisphere. Eg. Sub Himalayan range (Option D ruled out)

Active Principles

Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine.

Mechanism of Action

Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium.

Symptoms (by system)
  • GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness.
  • CVS: Hypotension, AV block, bradycardia, chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse. (Option B ruled out)
  • CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness.
  • MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms.
  • RS: Slow, labored, shallow breathing.
  • Ocular: Alternating pupil dilation/contraction (hippus), diplopia, impaired vision.
  • Others: Subnormal temperature, cold skin, yellow-green vision, tinnitus, paralysis of facial muscles.
  • Death: Respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation.

Fatal Dose

Root: 1-2 g

Treatment
  • No specific antidote.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid/activated charcoal.
  • Inotropic therapy for hypotension, atropine for bradycardia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ventricular arrhythmia treated with amiodarone, flecainide; cardiopulmonary bypass for refractory cases.

Medico-legal Aspects
  • Ideal homicidal poison: cheap, easily available, small lethal dose, short fatal period, difficult to detect postmortem.
  • Accidental poisoning: mistaken for horseradish

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nigella sativa

Explanation:

  • Nigella sativa (black seed) is a medicinal plant from the Ranunculaceae family, widely used in traditional medicines like Unani, Ayurveda, and Tibb-e-Nabwi.
  • These are small, black, angular seeds commonly known as black cumin or kalonji, used in cooking and traditional medicine.
  • Therapeutic Uses: It has various health benefits, including anti-hypertensive, anti-diabetic, anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and hepatoprotective properties.
  • Key Component: The active compound, thymoquinone, in the oil and seeds, is responsible for most of its therapeutic effects.
  • Common Uses: It is used to treat conditions like bronchitis, asthma, diarrhea, rheumatism, and skin disorders, and also as a digestive aid, appetite stimulant, and immune booster.
  • Cultural Significance: Considered a "miracle herb," it is $highly regarded in Islamic medicine, where it is believed to cure all diseases except death.

Incorrect Options:

Tropicana canna (Option A): The seeds are large, spherical, and hard, typically used as beads or ornaments. They do not resemble the smaller, black, and shiny seeds of Nigella sativa.

Datura seeds (Option C): Datura seeds are flat, kidney-shaped, and brownish-yellow, distinct from the black seeds of Nigella sativa.

Opium seeds (Option D): Also known as poppy seeds, they are small, round, and greyish-blue, distinctly different in color and texture from Nigella sativa seeds.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of snakebite in India?

choices.text: Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV
ASV is the mainstay of treatment
Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite

Explanation:

  • Atropine and neostigmine are not routinely used as primary treatment for krait bites.
  • While neostigmine may assist in reversing neurotoxic paralysis caused by snake venom (e.g., postsynaptic blockade in some bites), its role is secondary to antivenom therapy and ventilatory support.
  • Atropine is given to counteract bradycardia caused by neostigmine but is not specific to krait bites.

Treatment of snake bite:

First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’

CARRY
  • Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible.

NO
  • No Suction
  • No Cautery
  • No Ligature
  • No Tourniquet

RIGHT
  • R: Reassure the patient
  • I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps)
  • GH: Get to the Hospital immediately
  • T: Tell history/symptoms

Pressure bandage
  • Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps.
  • Contraindicated in viper bites.
  • Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg.

ASV
  • Mainstay of treatment.
  • Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present
  • Polyvalent anti snake venom (PAV) used in India can neutralize (i) Cobra (ii) Krait (iii) Russel viper (iv) Saw-scaled viper bites.
  • Dose: 1-2 ml/kg (!0 vials) irrespective of sex/age.
  • Each vial: neutralizes 6-8 mg of snake venom
  • Test dose is not required/advised to be given before initiating ASV.
  • Ideally to be given within 4 hours of snake bite.
  • To be given until clinical improvement (in cobra bites)/ Clotting time becomes normal (in viper bites).

Adjuvant treatment
  • Neostigmine 1.5mg: for neuroparalytic symptoms (cobra bite).
  • Atropine 0.5mg: To antagonize muscarinic actions of Ach.
  • Surgical debridement and FFP may be required in Viper bites.


Incorrect Options:

Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV (Option B): Neostigmine may help reverse neurotoxic effects (especially postsynaptic) when combined with ventilatory support. Anti-snake venom (ASV) remains the primary treatment.

ASV is the mainstay of treatment (Option C): Polyvalent ASV is the mainstay for treating bites from the "big four" venomous snakes in India (cobra, krait, Russell's viper, and saw-scaled viper).

Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper (Option D): The polyvalent ASV available in India is ineffective against humped pit viper venom because it does not include antibodies specific to this species.

questions.text:
Match the following poisons with their probable mechanism of action:


	
		
			
			A. Zinc chloride
			
			
			1. Abortifacient
			
		
		
			
			B. Chloral hydrate
			
			
			2. Irritant
			
		
		
			
			C. Quinine
			
			
			3. Corrosive
			
		
		
			
			D. Potassium carbonate
			
			
			4. Stupefying
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

Zinc chloride (A-2): Acts as an irritant due to its caustic effect on tissues.

Chloral hydrate (B-4): Causes stupefaction due to its sedative-hypnotic action.

Quinine (C-1): Known for its abortifacient property as it can stimulate uterine contractions.


Potassium carbonate (D-3): Functions as a corrosive agent due to its strong alkali nature.

questions.text: What is the drug that commonly leads to physical dependence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Heroin

Explanation:

  • Heroin, also known as diamorphine, is an opioid drug that is derived from morphine. It is highly addictive and is known to cause physical dependence.
  • When individuals use heroin regularly, their body adapts to the presence of the drug, and they develop a tolerance to its effects. This means that over time, they require higher doses of heroin to achieve the desired effect.
  • If a person becomes physically dependent on heroin and abruptly stops using it or significantly reduces its dosage, they may experience withdrawal symptoms.
  • These symptoms can be severe and include cravings, restlessness, muscle and bone pain, insomnia, gastrointestinal distress, and flu-like symptoms.

Heroin:

Drug Class

Opioid (Narcotic)

Origin

Derived from morphine, which is extracted from the opium poppy plant.

Forms

Powder (white or brown), black tar (sticky resin)

Route of Administration

Injected, smoked, snorted, orally ingested

Effects
  • Euphoria
  • Pain relief
  • Relaxation
  • Drowsiness
  • Slowed breathing
  • Sedation

Symptoms
  • Drowsiness
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Slow or shallow breathing
  • Unconsciousness
  • Overdose
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness

Long-Term Risks
  • Addiction
  • Liver and kidney damage
  • Collapsed veins (if injected)
  • Lung complications
  • Brain damage
  • Overdose

Withdrawal Symptoms
  • Anxiety
  • Sweating
  • Muscle pain
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Insomnia
  • Cravings

Overdose Symptoms
  • Slow or difficult breathing
  • Blue lips or nails
  • Unconsciousness
  • Pinpoint pupils
  • Death

Treatment
  • Methadone or buprenorphine replacement therapy
  • Counseling and rehabilitation.

 

Ketamine (Option A) is a dissociative anesthetic that produces hallucinogenic effects. While it can lead to psychological dependence, it is not typically associated with significant physical dependence.

LSD (Option C) is a hallucinogenic drug that does not typically produce physical dependence. However, it can lead to psychological dependence or addiction in some individuals.

Phencyclidine (Option D) is a dissociative drug that can cause hallucinations, distorted perceptions, and other psychological effects. It is not commonly associated with physical dependence, but it can lead to psychological dependence in some cases.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Arsenic·

Explanation:

  • Arsenic is a poison that can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. It has the ability to accumulate in bones over time, making it detectable even after the decomposition of soft tissues. Arsenic is a heavy metal, it replaces phosphorus and gets absorbed into the bones, where it may remain for years.

 

Postmortem findings of Arsenic Poisoning

External findings

Internal findings

  • Emaciation
  • Raindrop pigmentation
  • Keratosis
  • Alopecia
  • White streaks on nails (Aldrich Mees’ lines)
  • Jaundice and muscle wasting,
  • Nasal septum ulceration.
  • Sunken eyeballs
  • Cyanosed and shrunken body.
  • Rigor mortis (sets in late and persists for a prolonged duration)
  • Reddening of stomach mucosa (red velvet or strawberry) due to gastrointestinal congestion.

  • Flea-bitten appearance of the stomach (due to focal haemorrhages).
  • The inflammation and presence of “rice water” contents in the intestines.
  • Subendocardial haemorrhages in the heart.
  • Fatty degeneration of the heart, liver, and kidneys.
  • Along with routine viscera and body fluids, the items preserved for chemical analysis are:
      • A piece of long bone (preferably femur)
      • A bunch of pulled scalp hair
      • A wedge of muscle
      • A small portion of skin (from the back of the trunk)

 

Carbon monoxide (Option B) is a gas that is produced during the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials. It is unlikely to be found in skeletonized remains since it is a volatile gas that dissipates quickly and does not accumulate in the body or bones.

Hydrogen sulphide (Option C) is a toxic gas that has a strong odor of rotten eggs. Similar to carbon monoxide, it is unlikely to be found in skeletonized remains as it is a volatile gas that dissipates rapidly and does not accumulate in the body or bones.

Phosphorus (Option D) is a chemical element that can be toxic in certain forms, such as white phosphorus. However, it is not typically found in skeletonized remains as it is highly reactive and tends to undergo chemical reactions or degradation over time.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty with greenish color skin and a rotten egg odour. The most probable poisoning could be.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydrogen sulfide

Explanation:

Hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) is a highly toxic gas with a characteristic rotten egg odor.

  • It affects cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase, similar to cyanide poisoning but with distinct features.

Key Features of Hydrogen Sulfide Poisoning:

  • Skin "font-size: 11pt; font-variant:normal; white-space:pre-wrap" > Greenish discoloration (due to sulfhemoglobin formation)
  • Odor: Rotten egg smell (from hydrogen sulfide gas)
  • Respiratory: Severe pulmonary irritation, dyspnea, and respiratory failure
  • CNS: Headache, dizziness, seizures, coma
  • Cardiac: Bradycardia, hypotension, sudden collapse
  • Rapid onset of toxicity due to cellular hypoxia
  • Mechanism: Inhibits cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain → cellular hypoxia → metabolic acidosis.

Incorrect Options:

Carbon monoxide (Option A): Cherry red skin, no odor.

Nitrite (Option B): Chocolate brown blood (methemoglobinemia).

Cyanide (Option C): Bitter almond odor, pink skin, rapid onset of toxicity.

questions.text: Cause of Opisthotonus is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strychnine

Explanation: Alkaloid from seeds of strychnos nux-vomica causes opisthotonus.

  • Opisthotonus is a severe form of muscle spasm where the body is arched backward due to involuntary contractions of the back muscles, especially the paraspinal muscles.

Cause:

  • Strychnine poisoning is the classic cause.

It acts as a glycine antagonist in the spinal cord, leading to:

  • Loss of inhibitory control in motor neurons.
  • Uncontrolled muscle contractions and spasms.

Cocaine (Option A): Causes CNS stimulation, tremors, seizures, not opisthotonus.

Codeine (Option B): Opioid, causes CNS depression, respiratory depression, not muscle spasms.

Curare (Option D): A muscle relaxant causing flaccid paralysis, not spasms.

questions.text: Identify the active toxin extracted from the poisonous plant in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-Hyoscyamine

Explanation: The above image shows Atropa Belladonna, also called the deadly nightshade.

  • It produces an active poisonous component called hyoscyamine.
  • The toxin may also be found in datura Stramonium (Jimson weed)
  • Hyoscyamine is an isomer of Atropine and has Anticholinergic and Antimuscarinic activity.
  • It is used as an antiemetic, anti-secretory and antispasmodic agent in the treatment of naused, motion sickness, allergic rhinitis etc.
  • Side effects include dryness of the mouth and eyes, tachycardia, palpitations, decreased sweating, and can also produce anxiety and restlessness.

Calotropis Gigantea (Option A): It is a purple colored flower which has an active poisonous principle called Calotropin, Calotoxin.

Digitalis (Option B): Also called purple foxglove where the poison acts by inhibiting Na-K ATPase channel.

Ricin (Option C): Produced by castor plant where it inhibits RNA polymerase and protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following features is characteristic of chronic mercury poisoning?

choices.text: Lead lines are visible on X-ray
Basophilic stippling of red blood cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ﻿﻿﻿Mad hatter's (intentional) tremor

Explanation:

  • Chronic mercury poisoning, especially from inorganic or vaporized elemental mercury, particularly in industries like hat-making and glass-blowing leads to a classical neuropsychiatric condition known as “Mad Hatter tremor” or Hatter’s shake.
  • It features intention tremors that worsen during voluntary movements, starting in the hands and progressing to other body parts.

Chronic mercury poisoning

Specific features

Details

Minamata Disease

Organic (Methyl) Mercury exposure from shellfish in Japan

Erethism

Shyness, depression, anxiety, loss of confidence, suicidal thoughts

Danberry Tremor

Coarse tremors in hands, lips, tongue; slurred speech; early symptom is worsening handwriting

Hatter’s Shake

Affects mobility (walking, dressing)

Glass-Blower Shake

Similar to Hatter’s Shake; it appears later

Concussio Mercurialis

Most severe form; bed-ridden with no activity

Mercurialentis

Brown discoloration of anterior lens capsule; seen via slit lamp; Visual Acuity is Intact

Acrodynia (Pink Disease)

Puffy, painful hands/feet; pinkish color; pruritus, perspiration; skin peeling similar to Kawasaki disease

Hyperkeratosis and Mees' lines (Option A) are classic signs of chronic arsenic poisoning, not mercury poisoning. Mees' lines are transverse white bands across the nails caused by disruption in nail matrix keratinization. Hyperkeratosis, especially on the palms and soles, and "raindrop" hyperpigmentation on the skin, are hallmark features of long-term arsenic exposure

Lead lines are visible on X-ray (Option B) is a feature of chronic lead poisoning. "Lead lines" appear as dense metaphyseal bands at the ends of long bones on X-ray. It is caused by disrupted bone remodeling due to inhibition of osteoclastic activity by lead

﻿﻿﻿Basophilic stippling of red blood cells (Option D) is seen in lead poisoning. It refers to the presence of small blue granules in RBCs, representing aggregated ribosomes. It occurs due to inhibition of pyrimidine 5’-nucleotidase by lead. It is a classic hematologic finding in lead toxicity

questions.text: Gastric lavage treated with silver nitrate gives a black colour in poisoning with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aluminium phosphide

Explanation:

  • Aluminium phosphide (ALP) is a pesticide and upon ingestion, it with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to release phosphine gas (PH₃), which is the primary toxic agent.
  • When silver nitrate (AgNO₃) is added to the gastric lavage or exposed to the gas emitted from the stomach contents, phosphine gas reduces silver nitrate to metallic silver, which appears black.
  • If phosphine gas is present, the silver nitrate paper turns black, due to reduction of silver ions to elemental silver. This is a classical bedside test for confirming ALP poisoning.

Malathion (Option A) is a organophosphate and it does not interact with silver nitrate.

﻿﻿﻿Mercury (Option B): though it is associated with dark precipitates in other tests, mercury does not produce a black color with silver nitrate in gastric aspirate.

﻿﻿﻿Barbiturates (Option D) do not have any chemical reaction with silver nitrate.

Match the following types of poisons with their corresponding examples


	
		
			
			Poisons

				Metallic irritant

Explanation:

Correct Match

Poisons
