questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding snake bites?

a.  Elapidae is myotoxic

b. Viperidae is vasculotoxic

c. Hyaluronidase is secreted by all snake toxins

d. Toxins travel through lymphatics and superficial veins
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) b, c and d

Explanation:

The Elapidae family (e.g., cobra, krait) venom is primarily neurotoxic, not myotoxic.

Neurotoxins act at neuromuscular junctions, causing paralysis. (Option a)

Myotoxicity is more commonly associated with sea snakes and some viper venoms.

Viperidae (e.g., Russell’s viper, saw-scaled viper) venom causes vasculotoxic effects -

Damages endothelium, causes hemorrhage, leading to DIC, shock, and local tissue necrosis. (Option b)

Hyaluronidase is secreted by all snake toxins,it breaks down connective tissue matrix and facilitates diffusion of venom into tissues. It is present in the venom of most (nearly all) snakes across families. (Option c)

Venom predominantly spreads through the lymphatic system and superficial veins, especially in low-pressure systems like limbs. (Option d)

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with pinpoint pupils and difficulty breathing after playing at home. What is the most likely substance the child accidentally ingested?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Opioid

Explanation:

  • Opioid ingestion classically causes miosis (pin-point pupils) and respiratory depression — the hallmark of opioid toxicity.

Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose.

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote)

                    ↓

Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine

                       ↓

Abstinence (Prevent relapse):

  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

questions.text: A deceased woman was sent for an autopsy. She was found dead in a locked room with a heat stove still running. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. CO poisoning

Explanation:

  • A locked room with a running heat stove is a classic setup for carbon monoxide (CO) accumulation due to incomplete combustion of fuel. CO binds to hemoglobin with ~200–250 times the affinity of oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin and impairing oxygen delivery to tissues. This results in hypoxic injury and death.
  • CO poisoning often occurs in enclosed spaces with faulty heaters, stoves, or car exhaust.
  • Clinical features include headache, dizziness, cherry-red skin, confusion, and loss of consciousness. Death results from tissue hypoxia despite normal PaO₂.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels.

Treatment: Immediate removal from the source and administration of 100% oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen therapy in severe cases.

Poison

Post-mortem Staining

Carbon monoxide

Cherry red

Cyanide

Brick red / Bright red

Hypothermia

Pink

Opiates

Black

Hydrogen sulfide

Bluish green

Aniline

Dark / Deep blue or brown

Phosphorus

Dark brown

Nitrates

Reddish brown

Asphyxia

Dark blue

Septic abortion (Clostridium perfringens)

Pale bronze

Incorrect Options:

Cyanide poisoning (Option B): Occurs in industrial accidents or smoke inhalation from fires; causes rapid onset of severe lactic acidosis and cardiovascular collapse, not typically associated with a running stove in a locked room.

H₂S poisoning (Option C): Hydrogen sulfide is found in sewage, petroleum, and industrial environments; it presents with a rotten-egg odor and rapid respiratory failure, not with the enclosed-room heating scenario.

Aluminium phosphide poisoning (Option D): Common in agricultural suicide cases; releases phosphine gas when exposed to moisture, causing severe cardiac toxicity, not linked to household heating sources.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain, throat irritation followed by vomiting that contains blood and bile, and diarrhea that initially appears bloody but later becomes colorless, odorless, and rice-water-like. On examination, a distinct garlicky odor is noted in the breath. Which of the following is the most likely agent responsible for the poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Arsenic:

Explanation:

  • Arsenic poisoning (acute) presents with severe gastrointestinal distress — abdominal pain, vomiting (may be bilious or bloody), and profuse watery diarrhea classically described as rice-water stools.
  • A garlic-like odor on the breath or from vomitus is a well-known clue.
  • This presentation closely mimics severe cholera-like illness but with systemic toxicity. Arsenic exerts its effects by binding to sulfhydryl groups and inhibiting cellular enzymes, leading to multi-organ dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Phosphorus poisoning causes GI irritation and organ toxicity, but it is more associated with luminescent vomitus/stools and hepatic injury, not the classic cholera-like diarrhea with garlic odor .

Option C - Aluminium phosphide produces phosphine gas leading to cardiovascular collapse and severe metabolic acidosis; it also has a garlicky odor, but diarrhea is usually not classically “rice-water” and severe cardiovascular features dominate .

Option D - Croton seeds act as an irritant poison mainly causing severe vomiting and diarrhea, but without the characteristic odor or metallic taste of arsenic .

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Methanol

 

Explanation

  • A "hooch tragedy" refers to incidents of poisoning caused by the consumption of illicit or adulterated alcohol.
  • Methanol, a toxic alcohol, is often found in illegally brewed liquor as a contaminant.
  • Ingesting methanol leads to metabolic acidosis, blindness, and potentially fatal outcomes due to its toxic metabolites, formaldehyde and formic acid.

 

Phosphorus (Option A): Phosphorus poisoning typically occurs due to ingestion of rodenticides or fireworks, causing severe gastrointestinal and hepatic damage. It is not related to hooch tragedies.

 

Mercury (Option B): Mercury poisoning occurs due to exposure to mercury compounds, causing neurological and renal toxicity. It is unrelated to alcohol adulteration.

 

Ethanol (Option C): Ethanol is the active ingredient in alcoholic beverages and is generally not the cause of toxicity in hooch tragedies. The issue "hooch tragedy" occurred when ethanol was adulterated with methanol.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with muscle weakness, diarrhea, and bradycardia. He was diagnosed with organophosphate poisoning for which atropine was administered. After atropine administration, which of the following changes are not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bradycardia

 

Explanation:

 

Organophosphate (OP) poisoning causes cholinergic overstimulation by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, leading to accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.

Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist, used to treat the muscarinic symptoms of OP poisoning.

OPC poisoning:

Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

Option Explanation Seen after atropine?
Bradycardia Reversed by atropine (muscarinic blockade) Not seen
Muscle weakness Nicotinic effect; not reversed by atropine Seen
Diaphoresis Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves
Nasal discharge Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves

Muscle weakness (option B): Remains because atropine does not affect nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Diaphoresis (option C): Caused by muscarinic stimulation → improves with atropine.

 

Nasal discharge (option D): Muscarinic effect → improves with atropine.

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin , slurring of speech , altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Datura:

Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

 

Incorrect Options

Option A - Morphine:
Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.

Option B - Cannabis:
Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.

Option D - Alcohol:
Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

questions.text: Aldrich mees lines and raindrop pigmentation in hand is seen in which poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arsenic:

Aldrich-Mees lines (transverse white lines across the nails) and raindrop pigmentation (brownish discoloration) on the hands are characteristic signs of arsenic poisoning. Arsenic is known to cause these distinctive dermatological and nail changes. Arsenic interferes with the keratinization process in the nails, leading to the formation of Mees lines, and can cause pigmentary changes in the skin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thallium:

Thallium poisoning can cause symptoms like hair loss, peripheral neuropathy, and gastrointestinal issues, but it is not typically associated with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Thallium poisoning does have its own set of diagnostic signs but these specific ones are not characteristic.

Option C - Cadmium:

Cadmium poisoning is associated with kidney damage and bone disease, not with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Cadmium does not produce the same dermatological findings as arsenic.

Option D - Lead:

Lead poisoning is associated with basophilic stippling of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Lead affects different body systems and has different clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Acute liver failure is a clinical feature of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Amanita Phalloides poisoning

Explanation:

  • Amanita poisoning causes acute liver failure. It is a wild mushroom known as the death cap mushroom. Amanita poisoning presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, enlarged and tender liver, jaundice, oliguria , mental confusion, convulsions and coma

 

Early mushroom poisoning

Late mushroom poisoning

Hallucinogenic mushroom poisoning

Species

Inocybe

Amanita phalloides

Amanita muscaria

Toxin

Muscarine

Amatoxin (Option A)

Muscimol

Symptoms

Cholinergic symptoms (DUMBBELLS)

Hepatotoxicity

Hallucinations, seizures

Treatment

Atropine

Thioctic acid

Silibinin

(hepatoprotective)

Supportive treatment

ATROPINE CONTRAINDICATED

OP poisoning (Option A) presents with pinpoint pupils and diaphoresis, liver failure is not seen

Belladonna poisoning (Option C) presents with tachycardia, hallucinations not liver failure

Morphine poisoning (Option D) presents with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils, liver failure is not seen

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic came with complaints of agitation, global confusion, disorientation, hallucination, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis, and autonomic hyperactivity after cessation of alcohol for 48 hours. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Delirium tremens

Explanation:Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 48 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by:

  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity
  • Coarse tremors

 

Delirium Tremens (DT)

Wernicke's Encephalopathy (WE) (Option B)

Korsakoff's Syndrome (KS) (Option C)

Cause

Acute alcohol withdrawal.

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often due to chronic alcoholism.

Often a result of chronic alcoholism and thiamine deficiency.

Onset

48-72 hours after the last drink.

Acute onset, typically develops over 1-2 days.

Chronic, long-term condition.

Symptoms
  • Severe agitation
  • Tremors
  • Hallucinations
  • Confusion
  • Seizures
  • Autonomic instability.
  • G - Global confusion
  • O - Ophthalmoplegia
  • A - Ataxia
  • P - Polyneuropathy
  • Anterograde and retrograde amnesia (Intact long term memory)
  • Confabulation
  • Memory impairment.

Cognitive Function

Impaired consciousness, confusion, disorientation.

Disorientation, confusion, and memory problems.

Severe memory impairment, with intact long-term memory.

Motor Symptoms

Tremors

Hyperreflexia

Muscle rigidity.

Ataxia (lack of coordination), abnormal gait.

Motor function may remain mostly intact.

Treatment
  • Thiamine
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Fluids
  • Electrolytes
  • Thiamine supplementation (IM/IV)
  • Fluids
  • Electrolyte correction.
  • Thiamine supplementation
  • Psychological support
  • Rehabilitation therapy.

Magnan Phenomena (Option D) refer to tactile hallucinations, such as the sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin, associated with cocaine use rather than alcohol withdrawal

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia and arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were observed on the body. The probable drug of abuse in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Cocaine

Explanation: Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system (CNS) stimulant known for causing tachycardia and arrhythmias, which are common symptoms associated with its abuse.

Magnan's Syndrome:

Aso known as "Cocaine Bugs," occurs in individuals who use cocaine.

It is a type of tactile hallucination where the person experiences the sensation of grains of sand or small insects crawling under the skin, causing itching (formication).

Formication is derived from the Latin word formica, meaning "ant," and refers to the feeling that tiny insects are moving across the skin.

Causes:

  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Menopause
  • Skin cancer
  • Herpes zoster
  • Physical or psychological side effect of substance abuse, including cocaine, amphetamines, and alcohol withdrawal (along with delirium tremens).

Options B, C, and D are not associated with Magnan syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the treatment of Datura poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Physostigmine

Explanation:

  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura poisoning because it is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor..
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Toxins and Antidotes:

Toxicity

Antidote

Mechanism of action

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine (Option A)

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme

Opium

Naloxone

Opioid receptor antagonist

Organophosphates

Atropine (Option B)

Pralidoxime

Muscarinic antagonist

Cholinesterase reactivation

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Replenishes Glutathione

Methanol

Fomepizole

Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Inhibits GABA receptors

Cyanide

Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach)

1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide.

2. Sodium nitrate (Option C): causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.

  • Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given.

3. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate.

Neostigmine (Option D) does not cross blood brain barrier

questions.text: In cases of alcohol abuse, in what substance is the blood typically preserved during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Sodium fluoride

Explanation: For toxic analysis, like in alcohol abuse, the ideal preservative for blood is sodium fluoride.

Various methods of preserving viscera:

  • Saturated salt solution
  • Formalin fixation
  • Freezing
  • Alcohol preservation
  • Formaldehyde solution
  • Formalin-alcohol solution
  • Frozen section
  • Liquid nitrogen

Specimens for Analysis

Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination.

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is suspected

 

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons.

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

Suspected (Option A)

 

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.(Option D)

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C)

.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns.

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

Formalin (Option B) is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses.

questions.text:
Which of the following substances are antidotes for cyanide poisoning?


	Amyl nitrate
	Sodium nitrate
	Sodium thiosulphate
	Benzyl thiocyanate
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 2, and 3 only:

  • The antidote used in the cyanide poisoning includes Amyl nitrate, Sodium nitrate, and Sodium thiosulphate.
  • This is called the Lily cyanide antidote kit

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: These are incorrect options.

questions.text: A patient presents with paraesthesia, tetany, muscle twitching, and muscle cramps, along with urinary crystals as shown in the image. These symptoms are typical of poisoning with what substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Calcium oxalate:

  • The above case scenario is diagnostic of Oxalic acid poisoning.
  • Signs and symptoms
    • Fulminant poisoning- Burning, sour or bitter taste in the mouth with a sense of constriction around the throat and burning pain from the mouth to stomach, radiating all over the abdomen. Nausea and eructation are immediately followed by vomiting which contains altered blood, mucus and
    • Acute poisoning- Tingling and numbness of fingers and limbs, weakness, paresthesia, carpopedal spasm*, hyperirritability of peripheral nerves (Chvostek/Weiss sign), tetany, convulsions, coma and death.
    • Delayed poisoning- Characterized by nephritis—uremia, scanty urine, hematuria, albuminuria, oxaluria (envelope-shaped calcium oxalate crystals in the urine are seen under microscope).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cystine:

  • Cystine stones are hexagonal or benzene shaped.

Option B - Xanthine:

  • Xanthine stones are very uncommon in urine.

Option C - Ammonium urate:

  • Uric acid crystals are rosette shaped.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white-colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. On examination, she has an irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopics. What is the suspected poison?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Barium carbonate:

  • Barium carbonate is a rodenticide which presents with classical features of areflexia and paralysis.
  • Other symptoms include- Tingling sensation, tremors, cramps, stiffness of the muscles, paralysis of the tongue and larynx, myoclonus, myalgia, flaccid quadriplegia, hypertension, arrhythmia, ectopic beats, ventricular fibrillation, irregular pulse, shock, cardiac arrest, pulmonary edema, mydriasis, vertigo, headache, confusion, convulsions.
  • Postmortem findings: Non-specific. Submucosal hemorrhages may be seen in the GIT.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aluminum phosphide:

  • Aluminum phosphide presents with hypotension, arrhythmias, acute CHF, shock, dyspnea, cyanosis, Oliguria, renal failure. altered mental state, restlessness, convulsions, acute hypoxic encephalopathy, coma. muscle wasting, tenderness, bleeding diathesis.

Option B - Zinc phosphide:

  • Zinc phosphide presents with dyspnea, lethargy, hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, pulmonary edema, metabolic acidosis, convulsions, circulatory collapse, coma and death

Option C - Warfarin toxicity:

  • Warfarin toxicity, the patient presents with abnormal bleeding, dark urine, dark stools.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a painful snakebite wound on his right foot. There are two fang marks with swelling and bleeding at the bite site. What is the first step in management?

choices.text: Sling or splint leading to immobilization
See the snake brought by a relative

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Sling or splint leading to immobilization

Explanation:

Initial management of snake bite involves the “RIGHT strategy.”

  • R: Reassure
  • I: Immobilize
  • G H: Go to the Hospital
  • T: Tell the appropriate history and symptoms to the attending doctor.
  • or coagulopathy, the recommended antivenom dose is 150-200 ml.

Management of Snakebite

Management

Details

Indications/Notes

First Aid
  • Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry)
  • Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No)
  • Reassure patient
  • Immobilize bitten limb (Option B)
  • Transport to the hospital quickly
  • Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms

Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time

Evaluation
  • Check for signs of envenomation
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time
  • Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function

Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae

Antivenom Therapy
  • Mild: 50 ml
  • Moderate: 50-100 ml
  • Severe: 150-200 ml

Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper.

Indications:

  • Haemostatic abnormalities
  • Neurotoxicity
  • Cardiovascular dysfunction
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Extensive local swelling

Antivenom Administration (Option A)
  • Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose
  • Infuse over 1-2 hours
  • Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours

Supportive Care
  • Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Antibiotics (if severe local reaction)
  • Manage respiratory paralysis
  • Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding

Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA.

Venom suction (Option C) is to be avoided in case of a snake bite.

See the snake brought by a relative (Option D) This is not necessary as the ASV available is effective against all the common venomous snakes in India. Hence, ASV is administered regardless of the snake that caused the bite.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisonings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Hydrocarbons

Explanation:

  • Hydrocarbons (such as gasoline, kerosene, or other petroleum products) are highly dangerous if aspirated into the lungs. They can cause severe chemical pneumonitis and aspiration pneumonia, so gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning.

Gastric Lavage in Poisoning Management

  • Gastric lavage is a procedure to remove ingested poison by introducing and withdrawing fluids through an orogastric tube. Its effectiveness depends on timing, proper technique, and patient-specific considerations.

Timing and Effectiveness

  • Most effective within 1 hour of ingestion (Option A ruled out)
  • Can be beneficial up to 4-6 hours in select cases
  • Beyond 6 hours, poison likely passes into the intestines, reducing lavage efficacy

Procedure Steps

Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Contraindications

  • Corrosive Poisoning: Avoid except for carbolic acid (phenol) to prevent perforation
  • Convulsant Poisons: Risk of triggering seizures (e.g., strychnine)
  • Comatose Patients: High aspiration risk
  • Volatile Poisons/Hydrocarbons: May cause aspiration pneumonitis (Option C)
  • Risk of Hemorrhage/Perforation: Avoid if esophageal varices or recent surgery present
  • Additional Contraindications to Emetics
    • Severe heart or lung diseases
    • Advanced pregnancy
    • CNS depression or seizures

Complications

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternatives to Gastric Lavage

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.text: Unknown substance consumption leading to tachycardia and red-colored halo is seen with?
questions.solution:
Correct Options: C) LSD

Explanation:

  • Tachycardia and visual hallucinations of red-colored halo are indicative of consumption of LSD.
  • LSD - Lysergic acid Diethylamide: Acid blotter or paper stamp or taken as fumes.
  • Obtained from rye fungus (ergot).
  • Increases serotonin level in the brain (only psychological dependence).
  • Associated with the trip (most common)
  • Good trip
    • Visual hallucinations and illusions
  • Bad trip
    • Anxiety
    • Panic attacks
  • Flashback phenomenon is seen (re-experiencing the past experience).


Incorrect Options:

Cannabis (Option A) (marijuana) use typically does not cause significant tachycardia. While cannabis can induce visual hallucinations in some individuals, they are more commonly associated with LSD and other hallucinogens.

Crack/ cocaine (Option B) use is known to cause tachycardia due to its stimulant effects on the central nervous system. Cocaine can sometimes induce tactile hallucinations of bugs crawling on the skin (formication).

Heroine (Option D) use is more commonly associated with symptoms such as sedation, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis).

questions.text:
Match the poisons and their site of action.


	
		
			
			A. Datura
			
			
			1. CVS
			
		
		
			
			B. Nicotine
			
			
			2. CNS
			
		
		
			
			C. Nitric acid
			
			
			3. SKIN
			
		
		
			
			D. Nux vomica (strychnine)
			
			
			4. SPINAL CORD
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4

Explanation:

Datura (A-2): Datura primarily acts on the central nervous system (CNS).

Actions
  • Anticholinergic effects: CNS stimulant initially (causing anticholinergic effects such as delirium, hallucinations, and confusion), followed by CNS depression (respiratory center).
  • Vagolytic action: Heart stimulation.

Nicotine (B-1): Nicotine affects the cardiovascular system (CVS) by stimulating nicotinic receptors, leading to tachycardia, hypertension, and vasoconstriction.

Nitric acid (C-3): Nitric acid primarily affects the skin, causing corrosive injuries, burns, and tissue damage upon contact.

Nux vomica (strychnine) (D-4): Strychnine acts on the spinal cord, causing excitation of motor neurons, leading to muscle spasms and convulsions.

Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonus- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:
  • Emprosthotonus- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

questions.text: A female was given morphine sulfate during labor for pain, following which she developed respiratory distress. Which of the following will be the correct antidote?

Correct Answer: A) Naloxone

Explanation:

Naloxone is the specific antidote for opioid toxicity, including respiratory depression caused by morphine. It works as a competitive antagonist at opioid receptors, rapidly reversing the effects of opioids.

questions.text: A male patient presented with a history of consuming an unknown substance. He exhibited increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, and bradycardia. What is management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atropine

 

Explanation

  • The symptoms described—sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, and bradycardia—are consistent with cholinergic toxicity, commonly caused by organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
  • Atropine is the first-line treatment for cholinergic toxicity. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that counteracts the effects of excessive acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, reducing secretions, bradycardia, and other parasympathetic symptoms.

 

Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

 

 

Calcium gluconate (Option B): Used primarily for hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, or calcium channel blocker toxicity. It does not address cholinergic symptoms.

 

Pralidoxime (Option C): Pralidoxime (2-PAM) reactivates acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates. It is used alongside atropine but is not the initial management step. Atropine is given first to stabilize the patient.

 

Obidoxime (Option D): Similar to pralidoxime, obidoxime is an oxime used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. However, it is not the primary treatment for immediate symptom control.

 

Learning Objective:

Antidotes and their mechanisms

Poisoning Type

Antidote

Mechanism

Arsenic

BAL (Dimercaprol)

IM, chelates arsenic for excretion.

Succimer (DMSA)

Oral chelation.

DMPS

IV, transitioned to oral chelation.

Copper

Potassium Ferrocyanide

Forms insoluble copper complexes, reducing absorption.

Penicillamine

Chelates copper.

Cyanide

Sodium Nitrite

Forms methemoglobin to bind cyanide.

Sodium Thiosulfate

Converts cyanide to thiocyanate for renal excretion.

Hydroxocobalamin

Binds cyanide, forming cyanocobalamin.

Dicobalt Edetate, Methylene Blue

Alternative antidotes.

Ethylene Glycol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase to prevent toxic metabolites.

Iron

Desferrioxamine

Chelates iron for excretion.

Magnesium Hydroxide/Sodium Bicarbonate

 

Note: BAL should not be used in iron, cadmium, or selenium poisoning due to formation of toxic complexes.

Precipitate iron, reducing absorption.

Lead

Sodium/Magnesium Sulfate

Forms insoluble lead sulfate.

Calcium Chloride/Gluconate

Promotes bone deposition of lead.

CaNa2EDTA + BAL

Chelation therapy for lead elimination.

Mercury

Sodium Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate

Reduces toxic mercury ions.

BAL (Dimercaprol)

Traditional chelator; oral agents preferred.

Methanol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Compete for alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing toxic metabolites.

Opium

Naloxone

Blocks opioid receptors, reversing opioid effects.

Organophosphate

Atropine

Blocks muscarinic receptors to manage cholinergic symptoms.

Pralidoxime (2-PAM)

Reactivates acetylcholinesterase.

Phenol

Magnesium Sulfate

Absorbs phenol in the stomach.

Phosphorus

Potassium Permanganate

Oxidizes phosphorus into harmless phosphates.

Strychnine

Barbiturates

Depress CNS, preventing seizures.

Thallium

Prussian Blue

Binds thallium in the intestine, preventing absorption.

questions.text: In which poisoning is cherry red hypostasis seen on post-mortem examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - CO Poisoning

Carbon monoxide poisoning causes cherry red discoloration of the skin, mucus membranes, conjunctiva, nail beds, areas of hypostasis, blood tissues and internal organs.

  • This coloration changes to dark green and then to brown as decomposition starts to occur.

Post-mortem changes associated with Carbon monoxide poisoning are:

  • Cherry-pink lividity: One of the classic signs of carbon monoxide poisoning is the development of cherry-pink lividity on the skin. This occurs due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, a stable complex formed when carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin, resulting in a bright pink or cherry-red coloration of the skin.
  • Discoloration of internal organs: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause discoloration of internal organs. The organs may appear bright red due to the presence of carboxyhemoglobin.
  • Pulmonary congestion and edema: Carbon monoxide can lead to congestion and fluid accumulation in the lungs, resulting in pulmonary congestion and edema. This can be observed during postmortem examination as fluid-filled lungs with frothy fluid.
  • Macroscopic changes in the brain: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause macroscopic changes in the brain. The brain may appear swollen and congested, and the white matter can show pink discoloration.

Hydrogen Sulphide (Option B): poisoning causes a rotten egg smell in the victim. The general signs of asphyxia are present along with signs of changing of the blood and viscera colour to greenish-purple and not cherry-red.

Yellow Phosphorus (Option C):is a potent hepatotoxin. Post-mortem findings include garlicky odour along with icterus of the body due to liver failure as a part of multiple organ failure which causes the death of the victim.

Hydrogen cyanide (Option D): is an extremely lethal poison. Post-mortem findings of hydrogen cyanide poisoning include glistening and prominent dilated pupils, frothy mouth, brick-red blood and cheeks due to impaired oxygenation of the tissues. The internal organs may be oedematous due to congestion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom associated with chronic cocaine abuse?

choices.text: Dilated pupils, rapid pulse and sweating.
Hallucination of insects crawling on the skin (formication).

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Dilated pupils, rapid pulse and sweating.

Seen in acute cocaine poisoning

  • Mechanism of action of cocaine: Inhibits the synaptic reuptake of Epinephrine, Norepinephrine, Dopamine, Serotonin.
  • All these substances will increase synaptic cleft.This will cause Sympathomimetic Toxidrome

Chronic Cocaine Abuse: Cocainism, Cocainomania or Cocainophagia

  • Tolerance for high doses
  • Rush (When excited) and crash (when depressed)

Triad of cocaine abuse:

  • Nasal / Palatal perforation
  • Black tongue and teeth
  • Gangrene of periphery (Nose tip, ear lobule)

Cocaine bugs is aka Magnan symptom or formication: This is tactile hallucination. It seems like insects, mice or rats are crawling on skin.

Treatment:

  • Antidote: Amyl nitrite to control heart rate and BP
  • Supportive and Symptomatic treatment
  • Fatal dose: Around 1g

questions.text: A 50-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurring of vision after he consumed local spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Fomepizole

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase.

  • Alcohol dehydrogenase catalyses the oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. Alcohol dehydrogenase also catalyses the initial steps in the metabolism of ethylene glycol and methanol to their toxic metabolites.

Features or symptoms of methanol poisoning:

  • Gastrointestinal Distress: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea are common symptoms associated with methanol poisoning.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Methanol toxicity affects the central nervous system and can lead to symptoms such as headache, dizziness, confusion, disorientation, agitation, and seizures.
  • Visual Impairment: Methanol poisoning can cause visual disturbances, including blurred vision, double vision, or complete loss of vision. This is due to the toxic effect of methanol on the optic nerve.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid and formaldehyde, which can lead to metabolic acidosis—a disturbance in the body's acid-base balance. Symptoms of metabolic acidosis include rapid breathing, increased heart rate, and fatigue.
  • Respiratory Distress: Severe cases of methanol poisoning may result in respiratory distress, difficulty breathing, and lung damage.

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Viper

Explanation

  • The symptoms described, including drowsiness, pain around the wound, bleeding, and blisters, are consistent with a viper bite.
  • Viper bites often lead to profuse bleeding due to the effects of venom-induced coagulopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Cobra (Option B): Cobra bites are primarily neurotoxic, causing paralysis, respiratory distress, and potentially death if untreated. While cobras can cause pain and local swelling, they do not typically cause the extensive bleeding or blisters seen with viper bites. Cobras do not usually cause such local tissue necrosis and blistering.

Wasp bite (Option C): Wasp stings can cause pain, redness, and swelling at the sting site, but they typically do not lead to bleeding, drowsiness, or blisters. The symptoms described here are more consistent with a venomous bite from a snake rather than an insect sting.

Scorpion (Option D): While scorpion stings can cause pain, local swelling, and sometimes neurological symptoms (such as drowsiness), they typically do not cause blisters or profuse bleeding at the sting site.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours.
  • Local: Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test)
  • Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary edema.
  • Complications: Tachycardia,hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had an arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Strychnine

Explanation

  • Strychnine poisoning is characterized by seizures and muscle spasms, often causing arching of the back (opisthotonus).
  • The patient is typically conscious between episodes, and the seizures are triggered by minimal stimuli.
  • Strychnine is a potent neurotoxin that acts by blocking inhibitory neurotransmission, leading to overstimulation of the central nervous system.

Source

Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India.

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord.
  • Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms

Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonos- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:
  • Emprosthotonos- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

Treatment
  • Immediate Care: Place in a dark, quiet room.
  • Anesthesia: Chloroform or intravenous barbiturate if spasms allow.
  • Adsorption: Administer animal charcoal to absorb free strychnine, or tannic acid if charcoal is unavailable.
  • Antidotes: Intravenous barbiturates to stop convulsions.
  • Muscle relaxants: Mephenesin, intravenous diazepam for anticonvulsant effects.

Autopsy Findings
  • Rigor mortis: Sets in almost immediately and passes off early.
  • Stomach contents: Remains of seeds may be found.
  • Delayed putrefaction.
  • Toxicological analysis: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera; brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis.

Incorrect Options:

Ricinus (Option B): Ricinus, derived from the castor bean plant, contains ricin, which causes gastrointestinal symptoms, organ failure, and hemorrhagic shock. It does not typically cause seizures with back arching.

Nerium odorum (Option C): Nerium odorum (oleander) contains cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart and can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and potentially death. Seizures and back arching are not characteristic features of oleander poisoning.

Datura (Option D): Datura contains tropane alkaloids, which cause delirium, hallucinations, and anticholinergic toxicity. Although it can cause seizures, it is not typically associated with arching of the back or the pattern of seizures described here.

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and constricted pinpoint pupils. Which of the following is likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Opioids

Explanation:

  • Opioid toxicity is characterized by the classic triad of altered mental status (e.g., drowsiness or coma), respiratory depression, and miosis (pinpoint pupils).
  • Hypotension may also occur due to vasodilation and reduced sympathetic tone.

Opium is extracted from the unripe poppy capsule (shown in the image below).

Opium:

Introduction
  • Dried extract from the poppy plant (Papaver somniferum)

Extraction
  • Obtained by vertical incisions from unripe poppy capsule (toxic part)

Toxic principles
  • Phenanthrene group: Morphine, Codeine and Thebaine
  • Benzylisoquinoline group: Papaverine and Noscapine

Mechanism of action (MOA)
  • Exhibits action via 3 receptors mainly - Mu(μ), Delta(δ) and Kappa(κ) receptors and release Endorphins.
  • Addictive potential is due to its action on Mu(μ) and Delta(δ) receptors
  • Action on Kappa(κ) receptor causes dysphoria - no addictive potential

Effects
  • Tolerability, Addiction, Dysphoria (κ-receptor)
  • Pruritus is a common adverse effect.
  • Other effects: Constipation, Respiratory depression, Urinary retention.
  • Tolerability is developed for all actions except: 3 C's
    • Constipation
    • Convulsions
    • Constriction of pupils (Miosis)

Fatal dose

Opium: 2 g

Morphine: 0.2 g

Codeine: 80 mg

Fatal period: 6-12 hours

Management

  • Support vitals: Use a respirator and other emergency procedures.
  • Decontamination:
    • Stomach wash with 1:5000 KMnO₄, leaving some solution in the stomach to oxidize any secreted alkaloid.
    • Perform lavage even after IV/IM drug injection, as it is secreted in the stomach.
    • Administer activated charcoal as the primary decontamination method.
    • Enema with sodium sulfate twice daily.
    • Whole-bowel irrigation for body packers.
  • Antidote:
    • Naloxone

Incorrect Options:

Datura (Option B): Datura poisoning typically presents with anticholinergic symptoms such as mydriasis (dilated pupils), dry skin, hallucinations, tachycardia, and hyperthermia, which are inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

Cocaine (Option C): Cocaine use usually leads to sympathetic stimulation, resulting in symptoms like mydriasis, hypertension, tachycardia, and agitation. These are inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

Amphetamine (Option D): Amphetamines cause increased sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as mydriasis, tachycardia, and hypertension, which do not match the pinpoint pupils and hypotension observed in this case.

questions.text: Among the listed options, which substance is not utilized as a chelating agent in cases of heavy metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oximes

 

Explanation:

Oximes, such as pralidoxime, are not chelating agents. They are used as antidotes in organophosphate poisoning by reactivating acetylcholinesterase, which is inhibited by the poison.

 

 

Deferiprone (Option A): Deferiprone is a chelating agent used to treat iron overload, commonly seen in conditions like thalassemia major. It binds to iron and facilitates its excretion.

 

EDTA (Option B): Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) is a well-known chelating agent used in cases of lead and other heavy metal poisonings. It binds metal ions, aiding in their excretion.

 

Penicillamine (Option C): Penicillamine is an effective chelating agent for metals like copper (used in Wilson's disease) and lead. It binds metals and facilitates their removal from the body.

questions.text: Black foot disease with peripheral neuropathy is seen in which metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Arsenic

Explanation:

  • Chronic arsenic poisoning is associated with "black foot disease," a condition characterized by gangrene of the extremities due to peripheral vascular damage.
  • Peripheral neuropathy is also a common feature, presenting as sensory and motor dysfunction.

Clinical manifestations of Arsenic Poisoning:

 

Acute Arsenic Poisoning

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning

Dermal

  • Hair loss
  • Mees lines (Aldrich-Mees line or Reynold’s line): Transverse bands of opacity in nails. (Option C)
  • Melanosis (neck, eyelids, nipples)
  • Bowen’s disease
  • Facial oedema
  • Hyperkeratosis

Black foot disease (Peripheral gangrene)

  • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pattern)
  • Skin cancer (commonly squamous cell carcinoma).

Ocular

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Lacrimation

Dimension of Vision

Gastrointestinal

  • Abdominal pain
  • Metallic taste
  • Garlicky odour
  • Dysphagia
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea (bloody or rice water)
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Weight loss

Airway

Upper airway irritation
  • Nasal septum perforation
  • Laryngitis
  • Bronchitis

Liver

Fatty degeneration
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Cirrhosis

Kidney

  • Oliguria
  • Uraemia

Nephritic changes

Neurological

  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Convulsions
  • Coma
  • Encephalopathy

Polyneuritis (glove & stocking type)

  • Tremor
  • Ataxia
  • Limb tenderness
  • Difficulty in walking

Haematological

–
  • Anaemia
  • Leucopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Basophilic stippling (Rare in arsenic poisoning and common in lead poisoning)
  • Karyorrhexis
  • Pancytopenia

Cardiac

Tachycardia

Hypotension

Cardiac arrhythmias

Hypertension

Myocarditis

Lead (Option B): Lead poisoning primarily causes motor neuropathy (e.g., wrist drop) and cognitive deficits, but it is not linked to black foot disease.

Mercury (Option C): Mercury poisoning leads to neurological symptoms such as tremors, erethism, and sensory disturbances but does not cause black foot disease.

Cadmium (Option D): Cadmium toxicity affects the kidneys and bones, leading to conditions like Itai-Itai disease, but it is not associated with peripheral neuropathy or black foot disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient was found unconscious in his backyard, the leaves of a plant similar to the one shown below were found scattered around him. He is now presenting with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irregular heart rate. Identify the plant given below likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Yellow Oleander (Thevetia peruviana)

  • Yellow oleander contains toxic cardiac glycosides, which can affect the heart's rhythm and function. Ingestion of any part of the plant can lead to symptoms like nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, irregular heart rate, and even death. The symptoms described in the case (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, irregular heart rate) match those associated with yellow oleander poisoning.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ricinus communis (Castor Bean Plant): Ricinus communis contains the deadly toxin ricin. While its seeds are highly toxic, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and potentially fatal organ damage, the symptoms described in the case (irregular heart rate) don't typically align with ricin poisoning. Ricin primarily affects the gastrointestinal system and other organs.

Option C - Datura: Datura contains tropane alkaloids that can lead to symptoms like hallucinations, delirium, dry mouth, blurred vision, and an increased heart rate. While some symptoms could match (such as irregular heart rate), the prominent gastrointestinal symptoms described in the case (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea) are not characteristic of Datura poisoning.

Option D - Papaver somniferum (Opium Poppy): While opium poppy can produce opiates like morphine and codeine, the symptoms associated with its ingestion include respiratory depression, sedation, pinpoint pupils, and potential overdose symptoms. The symptoms described in the case (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, irregular heart rate) do not align well with opium poppy poisoning.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism goes to a liquor store and purchases two bottles of liquor. Approximately one hour later, after consuming alcohol, he presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal discomfort, acute confusion, vision loss, and an unsteady gait. What is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ethyl alcohol

  • The patient's presentation with abdominal discomfort, acute confusion, vision loss, and an unsteady gait after consuming alcohol are suggestive of methanol poisoning.
  • Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for the same enzyme, alcohol dehydrogenase, thereby preventing the formation of toxic metabolites (formaldehyde and formic acid) from methanol.
  • This treatment helps to reduce the toxic effects and allows time for methanol to be excreted unchanged by the kidneys.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and was unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Datura, Physostigmine

Explanation

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.

Clinical features:

  • Dryness of mouth and throat
  • Dysphagia
  • Difficulty in talking
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Flushed face
  • Pupil dilatation
  • Photophobia + Diplopia
  • Agitation and restlessness
  • Delirium
  • Urinary retention
  • Dry and hot skin
  • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Pralidoxime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning (which inhibits acetylcholinesterase), but it is not effective in treating anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura or yellow oleander. It works by reactivating acetylcholinesterase that has been inhibited by organophosphates. (Option A & C ruled out)

Yellow oleander poisoning is due to cardiac glycosides and can cause symptoms such as vomiting, arrhythmias, and confusion. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning is Digoxin-specific antibody or anti-digoxin antibody therapy, or the use of potassium correction and Lidocaine for arrhythmias. (Option C & D ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency room. On examination, his PR is 50 bpm, BP is 80/60 mmHg, RR is 7 breaths/min and his temperature is 95° F. He has a pinpoint pupil and is disoriented. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Opioid intoxication:

  • Opioid intoxication is characterized by respiratory depression, bradycardia, and pinpoint pupils.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Benzodiazepine overdose: Benzodiazepines are central nervous system depressants that can cause respiratory depression, hypotension, and decreased level of consciousness. However, benzodiazepine overdose is less likely to cause bradycardia and pinpoint pupils. The patient's presentation is more consistent with opioid intoxication.

Option B - Cocaine intoxication: Cocaine is a stimulant drug that can cause tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, and agitation. The patient's presentation is inconsistent with cocaine intoxication. Cocaine use is more likely to cause hyperthermia, tachycardia, and dilated pupils, rather than hypothermia, bradycardia, and pinpoint pupils.

Option C - Opioid withdrawal: Opioid withdrawal is characterized by symptoms such as sweating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dilated pupils, and agitation. The patient's presentation is inconsistent with opioid withdrawal. Opioid withdrawal is more likely to cause tachycardia, rather than bradycardia, and elevated respiratory rate, rather than decreased respiratory rate.

questions.text: A 23-year-old farm worker from a remote village was brought to the hospital 8 hours later, following a snake bite at 5 in the morning. The patient complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness and vertigo and had multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. He has signs of respiratory depression and bradycardia (HR<50). The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. He was administered 10 vials of antivenom. Which of the following is the subsequent step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neostigmine with atropine:

  • The subsequent step of management for this patient with snakebite envenomation would be Neostigmine with Atropine.
  • The symptoms described suggest that the patient may be experiencing neurotoxic effects of the snake venom, which can cause respiratory depression, bradycardia, and other neurological symptoms.
  • Antivenom is an important component of snakebite treatment, but it may not reverse the neurological effects of the venom, which can persist even after neutralization of the venom's systemic effects.
  • Neostigmine with Atropine is a treatment option for such cases of neurotoxicity, as it can help to reverse neuromuscular paralysis caused by snake venom.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Check the blood coagulation profile: Checking the blood coagulation profile may be necessary in cases of snakebite envenomation caused by venom that can cause coagulopathy. However, in this case, there are no apparent bleeding manifestations described

Option C - Epinephrine injection: Epinephrine injection is not indicated for this patient because the symptoms described are not consistent with anaphylaxis, which is the primary indication for epinephrine administration.

Option D - I.V hydrocortisone: I.V hydrocortisone is not indicated for this patient because it is not effective in treating the neurotoxic effects of snake venom.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses give the hematological picture as given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Saturnism:

  • Saturnism, also known as chronic lead poisoning, can cause a variety of hematological abnormalities, including anemia, basophilic stippling, and the presence of nucleated red blood cells (RBCs) in the peripheral blood.

  • In severe cases, lead poisoning can also lead to bone marrow suppression, which can result in pancytopenia.

  • However, it is important to note that the hematological picture of lead poisoning can vary depending on the level and duration of exposure, as well as individual factors such as age and nutritional status.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Minamata disease: While it is possible that mercury toxicity may lead to some degree of hematological abnormalities, such as anemia, the typical hematological picture of Minamata disease does not include specific features that would clearly distinguish it from other causes of anemia.

Option C - Chronic iron toxicity: Chronic iron toxicity can lead to a hematological picture of microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is characterized by small red blood cells that contain insufficient hemoglobin. While this is a specific hematological feature that can be seen in chronic iron toxicity, it is not unique to this condition and can also occur in other forms of anemia.

Option D - Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning can lead to a variety of hematological abnormalities, including anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The specific hematological picture may vary depending on the severity and duration of exposure. However, the presence of anemia alone is not specific enough to diagnose arsenic poisoning, as anemia can also occur in many other conditions.

questions.text: A 28 year old man presented with dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation after consuming an unknown substance. On examination, his PR 110 bpm, and his pupils were dilated. What did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Belladona: 

  • Belladonna, also known as deadly nightshade, contains tropane alkaloids such as atropine and scopolamine. These substances are known to cause anticholinergic effects, which include dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, increased heart rate (tachycardia), and dilated pupils (mydriasis).

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Heroin: Heroin is an opioid drug that acts on opioid receptors in the central nervous system. While opioids like heroin can cause respiratory depression, they typically do not produce significant anticholinergic effects. Common effects of heroin use include euphoria, drowsiness, pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and constipation. Dry mouth, urinary retention, and dilated pupils are not typical symptoms associated with heroin use.

Option B - Morphine: Morphine is another opioid drug with similar effects to heroin. Like heroin, morphine primarily acts on opioid receptors and can cause respiratory depression and constipation. However, it does not typically produce pronounced anticholinergic effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and dilated pupils.

Option C - Malathion: Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide. Ingestion of malathion can lead to symptoms such as excessive salivation, sweating, and constricted pupils (miosis), rather than the anticholinergic effects described in the case.

questions.text:
Which of the following are toxins?


	Atropine
	Colchicine
	Curare
	Arsenic
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2, 3 are correct:

  • 1, 2 and 3 are correct. Atropine, colchicine, and curare are all toxins.

  • Atropine, colchicine, and curare are substances that possess toxic properties.

  • Atropine is a naturally occurring substance found in certain plants, colchicine is a toxic alkaloid found in the autumn crocus plant, and curare refers to a group of natural toxins obtained from South American plants. Arsenic, on the other hand, is not classified as a toxin, but rather as a toxic element.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - All are correct: This option is incorrect because arsenic is not considered a toxin.

Option C -1, 3 are correct: This option is incorrect because it fails to include colchicine (option 2), which is indeed a toxin.

Option D - 3, 4 are correct: This option is incorrect because it includes arsenic (option 4), which is not a toxin

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer was presented in the hospital with pinpoint pupil & increased secretions. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Organophosphorus poisoning:

Organophosphorus poisoning generally occurs after respiratory, oral, or dermal exposure to nerve agents or organophosphorus pesticides. The onset symptoms of this specific disease are excessive lacrimation and saliva production, tiny pupils(miosis) , vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sweating, confusion, etc. So, as farmers are experiencing pinpoint pupils and increased secretion, the diagnosis is organophosphorus poisoning.

  • The primary treatment of Organophosphorus poisoning in emergency cases is stabilization. The experts will stabilize the breathing, decontaminate the body to stop further exposure and use intravenous fluids to clear the system from the toxins.
  • But, in non-emergency cases, the healthcare provider will give supportive therapy and stabilize the breathing using atropine (drug).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alcohol poisoning: Alcohol poisoning is a severe and deadly condition. It quickly affects heart rate, breathing, gag reflex, and body temperature. So, it often leads to coma and even death.

Option B - Opioid poisoning: Opioid poisoning occurs when there is excessive stimulation on the pathway of opiate. It eventually leads to lower respiratory effort and death. It can also cause pinpoint pupils but there is no increased body secretions.

Option D: Datura poisoning: Datura poisoning after 60 minutes of ingestion. The symptoms are dry skin and mouth, respiratory arrest, urinary retention, delirium, and tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image shown below?

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Only the roots of this plant are poisonous:

  • Aconite, also known as monkshood or wolfsbane, is a highly toxic plant. It contains various alkaloids, including aconitine, which is responsible for its poisonous properties.

  • The incorrect statement in this case is that only the roots of the plant are poisonous.

  • In reality, all parts of the aconite plant are considered poisonous, including the roots, stems, leaves, and flowers.

  • The plant contains toxic alkaloids throughout its structure, not just in the roots. Therefore, it is important to exercise caution and avoid direct contact or ingestion of any part of the aconite plant.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Causes AV block: Aconite is known to have potent cardiac effects. It can cause significant cardiac toxicity, including cardiac arrhythmias and disturbances in conduction, such as AV block. These effects are attributed to the toxic alkaloids present in the plant, particularly aconitine. Therefore, it is correct to state that aconite can cause AV block.

Option C - Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning: In cases of aconite poisoning, the primary treatment is supportive care and immediate medical attention. Activated charcoal may be administered to help prevent absorption of the toxin. Additionally, supportive measures such as cardiac monitoring, intravenous fluids, and management of arrhythmias may be necessary. Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning and may not effectively counteract the toxic effects of aconite alkaloids. 

Option D - Grow in sub Himalayan range: This statement is correct it grows in Himalayan range and used in various kind of herbal medicine.

questions.text: What is the cause of death in smoke inhalation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anemic hypoxia:

  • Smoke inhalation can lead to anemic hypoxia as the cause of death. Anemic hypoxia occurs when there is a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In the case of smoke inhalation, the inhaled smoke can contain toxic substances such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen cyanide (HCN). These substances can interfere with the normal binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in red blood cells, resulting in reduced oxygen transport throughout the body.

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) is particularly problematic as it has a strong affinity for hemoglobin and forms carboxyhemoglobin, which prevents the binding of oxygen. Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) interferes with cellular respiration and inhibits the utilization of oxygen by cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Histotoxic hypoxia: Histotoxic hypoxia refers to the inability of the body tissues to effectively use oxygen, even when an adequate amount of oxygen is available. It typically occurs due to the impairment of cellular metabolism or function, such as in cases of certain drug overdoses. Histotoxic hypoxia is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation.

Option B - Ischemic hypoxia: Ischemic hypoxia is caused by a reduced blood supply to tissues, resulting in insufficient oxygen delivery. It can occur due to conditions like cardiac arrest or severe blood loss. While smoke inhalation can lead to tissue damage and potential ischemia in specific cases, it is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation.

Option D - All of the above: This option is incorrect because all the given options are not correct.

questions.text:
Which of  the following statements about digoxin toxicity are true:

A. Pain in abdomen, burning sensation, diarrhea seen in digoxin toxicity

B. Vision changes like Transient ambylopia, photophobia, may be noted in digoxin toxicity

C. Specific antidote for cardiac arrhythmias is lignocaine 100 mg IV or novocaine or propranolol.

D. Death occurs from  Respiratory failure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A, B, C:

Statements A: Pain in abdomen, burning sensation, diarrhea seen in digoxin toxicity .This statement is true. Gastrointestinal symptoms, like Nausea, vomiting, pain in abdomen, burning sensation, diarrhea.

Statements B: Vision changes like Transient ambylopia, photophobia, may be noted in digoxin toxicity: This statement is true. Digoxin toxicity can cause Transient ambylopia, blurring, photophobia, scotoma, diplopia, color aberration

Statements C: Specific antidote for cardiac arrhythmias is lignocaine 100 mg IV or novocaine or propranolol. This statement is true. 

Manifestations of digoxin toxicity:

  • Digoxin toxicity can present with various signs and symptoms. The earliest manifestations often involve the gastrointestinal system, Nausea, vomiting, pain in abdomen, burning sensation, diarrhea.

  • Cardiovascular effects: Bradycardia, extra systoles, ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation, atrial fibrillation, faintness, precordial oppression, heart block.

  • Neurological effects: Headache, fatigue, confusion, anxiety, depression, disorientation, drowsiness, hallucinations, delirium.

  • Respiratory system: Labored and sighing respiration

  • The patient becomes drowsy and the condition may deepen into coma. Convulsions may precede death.

  • Death occurs from cardiovascular collapse.

Treatment

  • ECG monitoring is necessary as a guide to treatment.

    • Gastric lavage is done with a solution of tannic acid.

    • Activated charcoal is given.

    • Purgatives may be given.

    • Atropine is given in a dose of 0.6 mg IV to treat bradycardia.

    • Potassium chloride may be given to reduce extra systoles.

    • Specific antidote for cardiac arrhythmias is lignocaine 100 mg IV or novocaine or propranolol.

    • Trisodium EDTA may help to lower serum calcium.

    • Symptomatic treatment

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D are incorrect.

Statements D: Death occurs from Respiratory failure. This is a false statement.

  • Death occurs from cardiovascular collapse.

questions.text:
Match the following poisons and test:


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Marsh test

			2. Silver nitrate paper test

			3. Cavett test

			4. Marquis test
			
			
			A. Opium

			B. Aluminium phosphide

			C. Cyanide

			D. Alcohol

			E. Arsenic
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-E, 2-B, 3-D, 4-A:

Column A lists the poisons, and Column B lists the corresponding tests. 

  • Marsh test: Marsh test is used to detect the presence of arsenic. It involves generating arsine gas from the sample and using it to produce a characteristic brown or black deposit on a cold surface.

  • Silver nitrate paper test: The silver nitrate paper test is used to detect the presence of cyanide. When exposed to cyanide, the silver nitrate paper turns yellow or brown.

  • Cavett test: The Cavett test is used to detect the presence of alcohol. It involves using potassium dichromate and sulfuric acid to oxidize the alcohol, producing a colour change.

  • Marquis test: Marquis test is used to detect the presence of opium alkaloids. It involves the addition of Marqui's reagent to the sample, resulting in a characteristic color change.

    • It can be used to test cocaine, opiates and phenethylamines.

 Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following types of toxins has the maximum damage potential?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Corrosive poison

 

Explanation:

 

Corrosive poison has the maximum damage potential among the listed types due to its rapid and extensive destruction of tissues upon contact.

Corrosive poisons (such as strong acids and alkalis) cause immediate and extensive tissue destruction upon contact, leading to severe burns, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, shock, and potentially rapid death. Their effects are both local (at the site of contact) and systemic due to rapid absorption of toxic byproducts.

 

Irritant poison (Option A): Causes inflammation of mucous membranes (e.g., GI tract), leading to vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Damage is usually localized and less severe than corrosives.

 

Alcohol (Option C): Causes CNS depression, hypoglycaemia, respiratory depression, and liver damage with chronic use. Not as acutely destructive as corrosives.

 

Opioid (Option D): Acts on central opioid receptors, causing respiratory depression and CNS effects. Lethal if untreated, but damage is reversible with prompt treatment (e.g., naloxone).

questions.text: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HCN poisoning:

  • HCN or Hydrogen Cyanide is a pale-blue or almost colorless gas or liquid with a bitter almond taste.

  • When it interferes with using oxygen in the human body, it directly affects our blood vessels, heart, brain, and lungs.

  • Additionally, the pink color of mucosa and skin appears because of the excessive infectious hemoglobin saturation.

  • Symptoms of HCN poisoning:

    • Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath

    • Rapid and shallow breathing

    • Rapid heart rate (tachycardia)

    • Chest pain or tightness

    • Dizziness or lightheadedness

    • Headache

    • Confusion or disorientation

    • Seizures or convulsions

    • Loss of consciousness

    • Nausea and vomiting

    • Abdominal pain or cramps

    • Skin discoloration (bluish appearance)

    • Eye irritation or redness (if exposed to HCN gas)

    • Cyanide-like odor (bitter almond odor) may be present in some cases

  • Treatment:

    •  Activated charcoal to absorb the toxin.

    • In severe cases, Cyanokit, hydroxocobalamin, and Eli lilly's antidote

Incorrect Options:

Option A - H2S poisoning: H2S poisoning is also a severe and fatal condition. The primary symptoms of this condition are headaches, tremors, nausea, delirium, convulsions, disturbed equilibrium, eye and skin irritation, rapid unconsciousness, and eventually death.

Option B - CO poisoning: CO poisoning can also be deadly. The most common signs of CO poisoning are vomiting, upset stomach, dizziness, headache, chest pain, and confusion. If anyone inhales excessive CO, it has the potential to kill that individual.

Option D - OPC poisoning: OPC poisoning is a known class of insecticides that occurs when a person is exposed to organophosphates. The condition's primary symptoms are a runny nose, glassy eyes, blurry vision, agitation, muscle weakness, narrowed pill, etc. In severe cases, it leads to coma or collapse.
